channel.title: Deobfuscator that doesn't (quite) suck
channel.description:
Look what I made for you, MITB!
This is by no means a definitive release; it kinds sucks and needs a lot of improvement. But, I figured that I'd be better off releasing it now that it pretty much works rather than holding onto it until my perfectionist ass gets around to making it... well, perfect. I've tested it over two versions of the client , the first one being the last recent (or second to last recent... dunno) and the most recent. 1 class was not decompiled in the last recent version, and 2 classes didn't decompile in the most recent. I'm not sure what the problem is exactly, but in order to protect my ego, I'm gonna chalk it up to some bug in JODE. So, just JAD that shit and you're good to go. Probably.
Anyone is free to contribute to this. That's why I released it. I don't really feel like explaining its structure (I just got my wisdom teeth taken out), so ask as many questions as you need answers to.
P.S. somebody can port the shell script to Windows. I don't feel like it. :)

Error: Class117.method1115:340 Class250.method2957:48 Class181_Sub1_Sub19.method1882:95 client.method55:352 client.method50:759 Applet_Sub1.method37:98 Applet_Sub1.run:260 java.lang.Thread.run:613 | java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException: 0 error_game_crash Exception in thread "Thread-3" java.lang.VerifyError: (class: Class133, method: method1271 signature: (IIIZIZIILClass181_Sub40;II)V) Inconsistent stack height 0 != 1 at client.method52(client.java:1540) at Applet_Sub1.method40(Applet_Sub1.java:174) at Applet_Sub1.run(Applet_Sub1.java:271) at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:613) [/quote]

learn to read threads before posting questions…

item.title: Deobfuscator that doesn't (quite) suck
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

thanks to frank_ i just found out that if you have multiple return statements within an exception handler, javac will generate different entries for each return. so take something like:

[code]int test(){
try {
int a = 1, b = 2, c = 3;
if (a < b)
return 1;
if (b < c)
return 2;

    return 3;
} catch (Exception e) {
    return 0;
}

}[/code] is compiled to:

[code]
int test();
Code:
0: iconst_1
1: istore_1
2: iconst_2
3: istore_2
4: iconst_3
5: istore_3
6: iload_1
7: iload_2
8: if_icmpge 13
11: iconst_1
12: ireturn
13: iload_2
14: iload_3
15: if_icmpge 20
18: iconst_2
19: ireturn
20: iconst_3
21: ireturn
22: astore_1
23: iconst_0
24: ireturn
Exception table:
from to target type
0 12 22 Class java/lang/Exception

13    19    22   Class java/lang/Exception

20    21    22   Class java/lang/Exception

}[/code]as you can see each entry goes until the next return instruction (0-12, 13-19, 20-21). they are different entries, but use the same handler

the exception table entries’ last instruction will be the return instruction if generated by javac will either be a goto instruction or a return instruction. keep in mind though, that the exception table will only end with a goto instruction if the return instruction is after the exception handler[br][br][size=1]Posted on: November 01, 2009, 01:40:32 am[/size][hr]just to prove my point, here is an example with a class from the rs client:

final boolean a(int); Code: 0: getstatic #484; //Field client.ib:Z 3: istore 4 5: iload_1 6: sipush -27135 9: if_icmpeq 14 12: iconst_0 13: ireturn 14: getstatic #499; //Field C:I 17: iconst_1 18: iadd 19: putstatic #499; //Field C:I 22: aload_0 23: getfield #568; //Field wb:[I 26: ifnonnull 49 29: aload_0 30: getfield #545; //Field yb:I 33: iconst_m1 34: ixor 35: ifne 47 38: aload_0 39: getfield #567; //Field q:[I 42: ifnonnull 47 45: iconst_0 46: ireturn 47: iconst_1 48: ireturn 49: iconst_0 50: istore_2 51: iload 4 53: ifeq 97 56: aload_0 57: getfield #568; //Field wb:[I 60: iload_2 61: iaload 62: iconst_m1 63: if_icmpeq 94 66: aload_0 67: getfield #568; //Field wb:[I 70: iload_2 71: iaload 72: iconst_0 73: invokestatic #650; //Method oo.a:(IZ)Ljh; 76: astore_3 77: aload_3 78: getfield #545; //Field yb:I 81: iconst_m1 82: if_icmpne 92 85: aload_3 86: getfield #567; //Field q:[I 89: ifnull 94 92: iconst_1 93: ireturn 94: iinc 2, 1 97: aload_0 98: getfield #568; //Field wb:[I 101: arraylength 102: iload_2 103: if_icmpgt 56 106: iconst_0 107: ireturn 108: astore_2 109: aload_2 110: new #248; //class java/lang/StringBuffer 113: dup 114: ldc #17; //String jh.A( 116: invokespecial #633; //Method java/lang/StringBuffer."<init>":(Ljava/lang/String;)V 119: iload_1 120: invokevirtual #635; //Method java/lang/StringBuffer.append:(I)Ljava/lang/StringBuffer; 123: bipush 41 125: invokevirtual #634; //Method java/lang/StringBuffer.append:(C)Ljava/lang/StringBuffer; 128: invokevirtual #632; //Method java/lang/StringBuffer.toString:()Ljava/lang/String; 131: invokestatic #653; //Method sp.a:(Ljava/lang/Throwable;Ljava/lang/String;)Lah; 134: athrow Exception table: from to target type 5 108 108 Class java/lang/RuntimeExceptionsince the exception entry’s final instruction is an ‘astore_x’ instruction (neither goto nor []return), decompiler will decompile with errors. if you changed the exception entry’s end_pc to 107, rather than 108, it would decompile with no problems

Read full topic

item.title: Deobfuscator that doesn't (quite) suck
item.dc:creator: @White_Castle White Castle
item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

Iirc, what happens is it looks like this in the client:

METHODBODY
RETURN
HANDLERBODY

So, I just need to fix it to fit that pattern and I’m set. Right?

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

they would expect it how javac generates it

something along the lines of

METHODBODY
GOTO END
HANDLERBODY
END

item.title: Deobfuscator that doesn't (quite) suck
item.dc:creator: @White_Castle White Castle
item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

My flow tranforms aren’t very solid, so that’s probably why the deobber fails on earlier versions. I basically tweaked it until JODE stopped giving me errors. You guys are welcome to fix them, because I’m kinda burnt out on this. Shit, maybe I’ll fix them, because I’ve got a lot of off time this week.

The problem is that I don’t really understand why the dumb RuntimeException catch expressions cause JAD and JODE to choke. If someone could enlighten me, that would be supercool.

Read full topic

item.title: Deobfuscator that doesn't (quite) suck
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:43, topic:303141”]The methods that have Class.forName in them are all labeled by a comment as ‘synthetic’, so it may be something that only happens in JODE.

edit:
I have incorporated this deobfuscator and decompiler into my script now:

http://www.moparisthebest.com/rs/getRS.sh

and am currently deobfuscating and decompiling all of the previously downloaded files, you can watch the output with me here:

http://www.moparisthebest.com/rs/nohup.out

As you can see this throws an exception and fails with all of the early versions (looks like every version before 555 crashes it), I don’t know why and can’t look into it right now, does anyone else have any ideas?[/quote]

synthetic means compiler-generated code that was only added to implement some language feature you tried to use; e.g. using a switch on an enum turns into a synthetic internal class that has an int[] from enumValue.ordinal() -> switch’d # and switching on the value values[enumValue.ordinal()]

Read full topic

item.title: Deobfuscator that doesn't (quite) suck
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

They are synthetic because the compiler is converting a RuntimeException.class statement to a Class.forName(“java.lang.RuntimeException”) statement. It is not an artifact of the decompiling.

JODE just fails when it comes to decompiling RuntimeException.class.

Read full topic

item.title: Deobfuscator that doesn't (quite) suck
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

The methods that have Class.forName in them are all labeled by a comment as ‘synthetic’, so it may be something that only happens in JODE.

edit:
I have incorporated this deobfuscator and decompiler into my script now:

http://www.moparisthebest.com/rs/getRS.sh

and am currently deobfuscating and decompiling all of the previously downloaded files, you can watch the output with me here:

http://www.moparisthebest.com/rs/nohup.out

As you can see this throws an exception and fails with all of the early versions (looks like every version before 555 crashes it), I don’t know why and can’t look into it right now, does anyone else have any ideas?

Read full topic

item.title: Deobfuscator that doesn't (quite) suck
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

.class works by doing ldc #XXX where XXX is the index to the constant_class entry in da cpool hence why when you decompile some code using aaa.bbb.CCC.class (aaa/bbb/CCC) it decompiles with aaa/bbb/CCC; e.g. RuntimeException.class -> java/lang/RuntimeException when using jad

Read full topic

item.title: Deobfuscator that doesn't (quite) suck
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

I don’t think they are trying to run Class.forName at all but trying to do Clazz.class. Nowhere in the client do I see and LDC that loads a class. Does anyone know why?

Edit: Turns out ASM says that the .class feature only came in class file version 49. Can anyone find the documentation for this? In terms of making a deob you could probably just change it out for an ldc but that depends on if jode can handle it.

Read full topic

item.title: Deobfuscator that doesn't (quite) suck
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I cleaned a lot of shit out of this thread, in the future abraham and super should just avoid responding to each other.

edit:
The first version of this produced a lot of errors, I just gave the latest version a shot with much better results, only one problem:

mopar@debian:~/test/deob/deob563src$ javac -cp .:/usr/lib/jvm/java-6-sun-1.6.0.12/jre/lib/plugin.jar client.java
./Class26.java:298: unreported exception java.lang.ClassNotFoundException; must be caught or declared to be thrown
        return Class.forName(string);

Same problem with 560, those are the only two I tested it on. This is in multiple classes where the exception was not checked and therefore the client is not compilable.

To fix it, simply run this command:

sed s/return\ Class.forName\([a-z]*\)\;\/try{\&}catch\(Exception\ e\){e.printStackTrace\(\)\;System.out.println\(\"mopar\ added\ this\ exception\"\)\;return\ null\;}/ ./*.java -i

So now my run.sh looks like this:

#!/bin/sh java -Xmx512m -cp .:asm-3.2.jar:asm-tree-3.2.jar:asm-util-3.2.jar com.esk.deob.Main o $1 deob.jar java -jar ZKM.jar zkm-script mv deob.jar $2 java -cp .:asm-3.2.jar:asm-tree-3.2.jar:asm-util-3.2.jar:jode-1.1.2-pre1.jar com.esk.deob.Main c $2 $3 sed s/return\ Class.forName\([a-z]*\)\;\/try{\&}catch\(Exception\ e\){e.printStackTrace\(\)\;System.out.println\(\"mopar\ added\ this\ exception\"\)\;return\ null\;}/ $3/*.java -i

Of course, a decent fix would change the com.esk.deob.impl.TryCatch class to not remove the try catch from around Class.forName() in the first place.

edit2:

mopar@debian:~/whitedeob/deob/deob561src$ javac -cp .:/usr/lib/jvm/java-6-sun-1.6.0.12/jre/lib/plugin.jar client.java ./Class199.java:222: unexpected type required: variable found : value int i_40_ = --(is_14_[i + 1][1 + i_15_] * 2) & 0x7; ^ ./Class53_Sub17.java:131: unexpected type required: variable found : value int i_27_ = ---i_11_ + i_7_; ^ ./Class53_Sub17.java:131: operator + cannot be applied to <any>,int int i_27_ = ---i_11_ + i_7_; ^ ./Class53_Sub17.java:131: incompatible types found : <nulltype> required: int int i_27_ = ---i_11_ + i_7_;

Well with 561 there is an error, I wonder what JODE decompiled into the ‘—’, strange…

Read full topic

item.title: Deobfuscator that doesn't (quite) suck
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“unlimitedorb, post:34, topic:303141”]YOU STOP POSTING SHIT MR. OVERLOADED OPERATOR

The behavior of shift overflow isn’t obvious. Q.E.D.
[/quote]we were debating whether it was undefined, not whether it was obvious

the behaviour is defined, stop posting shit

isnt that obvious? if you shift something 33 times, its the same as shifting once…

Ah, so you are unaware of the wonderful world of undefined behavior? Good for you ^^

“on the contrary, the behavior is defined”

[b]“I never said it wasn’t…”

“I never said it wasn’t…”

“I never said it wasn’t…”

“I never said it wasn’t…”

“I never said it wasn’t…”[/b]

You obviously missed something… why am I not surprised? HHAHAHAHHHAHAHHAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA[/quote]
what exactly did you mean? your original post made little sense

[quote=“unlimitedorb, post:23, topic:303141”][quote author=la­wl link=topic=399396.msg2991831#msg2991831 date=1255318441]
isnt that obvious? if you shift something 33 times, its the same as shifting once…

Ah, so you are unaware of the wonderful world of undefined behavior? Good for you ^^[/quote]

edit: i guess i misread the first time and it stuck with me afterwards. the great thing about java is all the behavior is what you would expect it to be, unlike some things in c++ etc.
